conclusion: Understanding how shadows change when the light source moves forward above the objects.
Key factors: position and intensity of the light source, relative positions of objects and surface.
Light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Objects are in fixed positions relative to each other and the surface.
Moving the light source forward makes it closer to the objects and surface.
Shadows become larger as the light source gets closer due to changing angle of incidence.
Shadow A is cast by the object on the left.
Shadow A becomes larger and more spread out as the light source moves forward.
Shadow B is cast by the object in the center.
Shadow B becomes larger and more spread out as the light source moves forward.
Shadow C is cast by the object on the right.
Shadow C becomes larger and more spread out as the light source moves forward.
Shadow D is cast by the object on the far right.
Shadow D becomes larger and more spread out as the light source moves forward.
All shadows will become larger and more spread out as the light source moves forward.
Final Answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become larger and more spread out as the light source moves forward.
